News and developments from Justia and the tech world -----
November 2016
 

Welcome to the November 2016 edition of 
the Justia monthly client newsletter!

Get an inside look at new developments in the online marketing world, keep up with the latest social media trends, and hear about what’s happening at the Justia offices as we give thanks to our clients and give back to the community!

Featured News

Google Assistant Joins Siri, Alexa, and Cortana as Newest Voice-Activated Personal Assistant

As voice search becomes more prevalent, Google has joined Apple, Amazon, and Microsoft in the race to develop the best voice-activated personal assistant. Featured on Justia’s Onward blog, this post provides an overview of how this new technology works, how it stacks up with competitors, and what it means for your site’s SEO.

Tip of the Month

Boost Your Search Engine Rankings With Solid Blog Content

Posting regularly to your blog can boost your ranking for targeted keywords and highlight legal acumen within your firm. Blogging also provides an opportunity to attract prospective clients online. Don’t have a blog? Contact us to discuss setting one up! Blog posts can be organized by category so visitors can easily identify topics of interest. In addition, your blog can include links back to your firm’s primary website, attorney profiles, and contact details, making it simple for interested parties to get in touch.

Tech News

FAA Bans Samsung Galaxy Note 7 From Flights After Smartphones Recalled, Discontinued

After nearly 100 reports of Galaxy Note 7 smartphones overheating, and in some cases injuring users or damaging property, the FAA has banned the devices from all airlines. This announcement represents only the latest blow to Samsung, which has already issued two recalls of this product and ultimately discontinued it.

House Wants “Briefing as soon as possible” to Grok How Yahoo Spied

Members of Congress have demanded answers from the Attorney General and Director of National Intelligence regarding reports that Yahoo received and complied with a 2015 government request to conduct warrantless searches of all users’ incoming email. Elected officials have expressed concerns over the constitutionality of such a request, and are calling for increased oversight of government intelligence programs.

US Renews Fight for the Right to Seize Content from the World’s Servers

Federal prosecutors have asked the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to reconsider a July 2016 decision by a three-judge panel finding that while federal law permits U.S. authorities to seize information on U.S.-based servers, it does not allow access to content on foreign servers. Closely watched by many in the privacy community, the media, and the business world, this case could potentially move up to the U.S. Supreme Court if the appellate court declines to reconsider its prior ruling.

The Federal Government’s Latest Project: Squirrel GIFs

Blending technology and history, the National Archives and Records Administration has created more than 160 GIFs from its collections of historic documents and records. Featured images come from sources such as newsreels, public service announcements, and agency records, and are all free for download.

Google Starts Highlighting Fact-Checks in News

Google recently announced that it has created a “fact-checker” tag for use in Google News. Content creators can add the tag themselves before posting stories, and the fact-check tag will be visible to users in the expanded view of new stories in both the desktop and mobile versions of Google News. The company indicated that the recent proliferation of fact-checking sites was one of its motivations in creating this service.

Twitter, Microsoft, Google and Others Say They Haven’t Scanned Messages Like Yahoo

Following recent reports that Yahoo built custom software to scan all incoming user email in response to a secret court order, other tech giants have swiftly distanced themselves from any notion that they participated in similar programs. Companies including Google and Twitter have stated that they have never received such a request from the government, and would oppose it if they did.

SEO News

With Google Assistant & Google Home, Google Seeks to Win the Hands-Free Generation of Search

After announcing Google Assistant at Google I/O in May 2016, the search company went a step further in October when it unveiled its own line of smartphones featuring the voice-activated personal assistant. The precise impact hands-free search will have on websites and SEO strategy is yet unclear, but given both the advantages and limitations of voice interactions between people and their phones, we can expect to see some changes over the coming months as more people start using Google Assistant to search. Also watch for the responses from Google Assistant’s competitors—Microsoft’s Cortana, Amazon’s Alexa, and Apple’s Siri.

How Mobile Has Changed the Way We Search, Based on 10+ Years of Eye-Tracking Studies

Studies that track users’ eye movements while they view a search engine results page (SERP) suggest that the increased use of mobile devices for search has affected how people view search results even on desktop, as compared to ten years ago. Specifically, users tend to do a quick vertical scan of search results, rather than spending much time on any one result.

Google My Business Testing Advanced Verification Process for Spammy Map Categories

Google is using a new spam prevention technique to try to reduce the amount of spam in its business listings. Called “advanced verification,” this new process is currently aimed specifically at locksmiths and plumbers (due to the high incidence of spam in local results in these industries), but it is not yet clear whether they will expand the scope to include other industries.

Google Penguin Looks Mostly at Your Link Source

Google’s Penguin search algorithm reportedly deemphasizes inbound links from low-quality sources instead of penalizing sites receiving those links. This addresses a common concern that many low-quality inbound links—even if they were unsolicited—have negatively affected the performance of a website.

Google to Divide Its Index, Giving Mobile Users Better & Fresher Content

Google recently announced plans to divide its search index into results for mobile users and results for desktop users, with the mobile index offering the most up-to-date results.This marks a crucial turning point for search, sparked by the significant increase in Google’s mobile users, which now outnumber desktop users.

Attorney Lee Berlik comments on the defamation lawsuit against Rolling Stone magazine over their retracted article about an alleged sexual assault at the University of Virginia.

Based in Westfield, New Jersey, the law firm donated money to the program and volunteered to work with its students in a show of support to future generations of young leaders and innovators.

Social Media News

Facebook Launches Workplace, a Business Version of Facebook

Facebook has created a separate version of its popular social network. Called Workplace, this communication tool was recently launched for businesses, nonprofits, and other organizations. The platform is not linked to users’ existing Facebook accounts, making it entirely autonomous in that sense, and is ad-free. Fees are based on how many employees an organization has that would be using the platform. Workplace is free for nonprofits and educational institutions, and aims to connect the professional sector of the Internet using features such as group chats, video calls, individual worker profiles, and newsfeeds.

Twitter Moments Can Now be Made by Everyone

Twitter’s Moments feature is now available to all users on the website version of the social network, with mobile anticipated to follow shortly. Every Twitter user can now tell stories through a series of linked tweets, videos, and images. Moments can also be used to track events such as news stories, concerts, and sports in real time.

Exploring a Newly-Granted Google Patent Around Social Signals

A recently published patent offers clues about how Google views social signals and search results. The patent includes details about how each online searcher has a social graph linked to them, one that is created via their social media connections on sites, blogs, in email, and chat, etc. When Google is able to connect a user between these various web properties, a fuller picture of their social graph and connections is made. Likes and recommendations by the people to whom they are connected socially could ultimately be used to impact their search ranking, as this patent seems to suggest that social interactions may now be used as a factor in search ranking signals.

Marketing via LinkedIn (Infographic)

The popular job networking site LinkedIn can also be used as a marketing tool. This infographic provides figures that make a strong argument in favor of advertising on LinkedIn, including its number of monthly visitors, various user demographics, and recent revenue growth. The infographic also includes tips on what to market and LinkedIn’s best practices for posting on its platform.

LinkedIn Announces Changes to Endorsements Feature

LinkedIn has changed how it presents the endorsement of skills in user profiles. The company now features endorsements from mutual connections first. LinkedIn has also improved how it is targeting suggested endorsements to connections who best know your skills and work.

Facebook Updates Calls to Action on Pages, Recommendations, Local Events

Recently, Facebook updated its recommendations, local events, and call-to-action buttons on pages for businesses. Recommendations can now be turned on for status updates where individual users are seeking advice. The events bookmark will also be updated in the coming weeks to allow users to browse recommendations for events by their popularity with friends. Lastly, Facebook has updated its calls to action for local business pages, allowing users the increased flexibility to request appointments, obtain a quote for services, order food from restaurants, and purchase tickets to events directly from a business’ page.

21 Secrets Behind Viral Infographics

Infographics can play an important role in your marketing strategy—if they’re used effectively. This article covers the best practices for creating infographics, detailing what should be included in the graphic, as well as why each inclusion is recommended.

Legal Industry News

Six Tips for Law Firms to Reduce Tech Security Risks

Law firm clients are increasingly requesting information about the way their attorneys handle their confidential information. This post provides a summary of six areas on which law firms should focus in order to beef up the security of their client data. These six areas are: two-factor authentication, encryption, data loss prevention, vulnerability scans, backup and disaster recovery, and security awareness training.
